Secondly, it contributes to an overall increase in the <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a><span> of the <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e present the CV curves for samples FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 over the initial five cycles within the voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V, employing a scan speed of 0.2&nbsp;mV S<sup>−1</sup>. Commencing from the third cycle, a pronounced alignment in the CV curves is evident, signifying the commendable reversibility of FeHCF-1 during cycling. Furthermore, the CV curves exhibit two discernible pairs of oxidation/reduction peaks at 3.0&nbsp;V/2.6&nbsp;V and 3.6&nbsp;V/3.25&nbsp;V. These peaks correspond to the redox reactions involving high-spin iron and low-spin iron, respectively. This observation aligns with the positions of the dual discharge plateaus discernible in the charge–discharge voltage plateau curves across different cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b). Comparative analysis with the CV curves of FeHCF-0 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e), synthesized without sodium salt-assisted methods, reveals a notably heightened intensity of the redox peak at high voltage in FeHCF-1. This enhancement is attributed to the introduction of sodium salts during synthesis, mitigating [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> vacancies and consequently fostering a greater presence of low-spin iron in FeHCF-1. This augmentation significantly contributes to the improved <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of FeHCF-1, consistent with the charge–discharge voltage plateau curves of diverse samples during the initial cycle (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c). Based on previous studies <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, the electrode equations governing the initial charging and discharging processes of FeHCF-1 are as follows:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">Low voltage plateau charging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">Na<sub>1.07</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.30</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.14</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.14Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.14e<sup>−</sup></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">High voltage plateau charging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.37</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>III</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56e<sup>−</sup></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">Low voltage plateau discharging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">Na<sub>0.37</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>III</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">High voltage plateau discharging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>1.37</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">And the electrode equations governing the subsequent reversible processes of FeHCF-1 are as follows:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">Low voltage plateau charging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">Na<sub>1.37</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44e<sup>−</sup></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">High voltage plateau charging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165">Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.37</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>III</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56e<sup>−</sup></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0170">Low voltage plateau discharging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175">Na<sub>0.37</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>III</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0180">High voltage plateau discharging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185">Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>1.37</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0190">The rate performance of various samples within the voltage range of 2.0&nbsp;V–4.0&nbsp;V is depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f. At current densities of 20, 50, 100, 200, and 500&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, the discharge capacities of FeHCF-1 are 104, 93.4, 83.5, 72.4, and 59.9&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively—significantly surpassing those of FeHCF-0. Specifically, at a current density of 500&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, FeHCF-0 exhibits a discharge capacity of only 48.9&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, whereas FeHCF-1 demonstrates outstanding rate performance. Upon restoring the current density of FeHCF-1 to 20&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, the capacity rebounds to 89.1&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, which indicates that the interface and structure of the sample FeHCF-1 are not damaged under the large current density.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0195"><span>The sodium-storage mechanism and kinetic aspects of the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-reaction" title="Learn more about electrode reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode reaction</a> were investigated through CV measurements of FeHCF-1 under varying scan rates. In </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a, within the voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V for FeHCF-1, the CV curves exhibit minimal distortion as the scan rate increases from 0.1 to 2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>. Notably, both pairs of redox peaks remain observable, indicating favorable sodium-storage reversibility in FeHCF-1. Analysis of current responses at different scan rates allows the distinction between pseudocapacitive and diffusion-controlled contributions during charge–discharge processes. Calculate the b value according to the formula: <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi></mrow><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="7.196ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 3098.3 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2209,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></script></span><span> (i is the peak current, v is the scan rate, and a is the coefficient). When the b value is close to 1, it indicates that the capacity in the reaction is mainly derived from the pseudocapacitive behavior, while the b value is close to 0.5, indicating that the capacity contributed by the diffusion behavior is dominant in the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> process </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. Referring to the CV curves of FeHCF-1, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b depicts a linear relationship between log(peak current density, i) and log(scanning rate, v) for oxidation/reduction peaks. The b-values for redox reactions induced by high-spin iron at low voltage are 0.826 and 0.686, signifying that sodium storage in low-voltage, high-spin iron is influenced by both diffusion and pseudocapacitive behaviors <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>. Conversely, b-values for redox reactions induced by low-spin iron at high voltage are 0.897 and 0.893, revealing that sodium storage in high-voltage, low-spin iron is predominantly governed by pseudocapacitive reactions. Taking the discharging process as an illustrative example, we further analyze the sodium-storage mechanism and the rationale for pseudocapacitive behavior in this sample. During the intercalation of sodium ions into the FeHCF framework, sodium ions initially occupy the body-centered position and subsequently migrate to the face-centered position <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>. This process initiates the reduction of low-spin Fe and mirrors the adsorption of sodium ions on the surface in pseudocapacitive behavior. Consequently, sodium intercalation at high voltage manifests as a pseudocapacitive behavior. However, in contrast to conventional pseudocapacitive behavior, the charge storage in this context occurs within the structure, leading to its classification as intercalation pseudocapacitive behavior <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. Subsequently, sodium ions intercalate into vacant body-centered sites, inducing the reduction of high-spin Fe. As a result, the b-value for the reduction peak at low voltage approximates 0.5, emphasizing the predominant diffusion nature of sodium intercalation. The Na<sup>+</sup><span> diffusion characteristics of FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1 during the charging and discharging processes were assessed using <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about GITT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">GITT</a> in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>. Sodium ion diffusion coefficients (D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup>) were calculated following Fick's law <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d illustrate the dynamic relationship between the diffusion rate of sodium ions and voltage during the charging and discharging processes. D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> exhibits dynamic changes throughout these processes. The diffusion coefficients for both FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1 decrease with increasing voltage during charging and decrease with decreasing voltage during discharging. Notably, the diffusion coefficient of the sample FeHCF-1 increased significantly at 3.43&nbsp;V during the charging process and 3.13&nbsp;V during the discharging process and is significantly higher than that of the sample FeHCF-0. This enhancement is attributed to the prevalence of low-spin iron redox reactions at these voltages in FeHCF-1. The sodium ions, engaged in intercalation pseudocapacitive behavior, become embedded in the crystal structure, markedly enhancing sodium ion transport kinetics. Additionally, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d reveal that the diffusion coefficient of FeHCF-1 consistently exceeds that of FeHCF-0, indicating a swifter Na+ diffusion rate during charging and discharging, this may be attributed to the relatively smaller size of FeHCF-1 particles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>. Consequently, FeHCF-1 demonstrates superior electrochemical performance compared to FeHCF-0 <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr4.jpg" height="419" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (372KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (372KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span>(a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a><span> curves of the sample FeHCF-1 at different scan rates. (b) Linear relationship between log(current) and log(scanning rate) of peaks in the <a href="/topics/chemistry/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of the sample FeHCF-1. Na</span></span><sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> of the samples FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 during the (c) charging and (d) discharging process.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0200"><span>To investigate the impact of sodium salt addition on the kinetic process of FeHCF, <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> measurements were conducted on FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 samples. In the Nyquist plot, the prominent semicircle in the high-frequency region corresponding to the interfacial membrane impedance (R</span><sub>SEI</sub>); the middle-frequency semicircle indicative of charge exchange impedance (R<sub>ct</sub><span>); the low-frequency oblique line corresponding to sodium ion transport in the solid-state diffusion process within the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode material</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a, we present varied voltage Nyquist plots of FeHCF-1 synthesized by adding Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> before cycling. Curves ranging from 3.6&nbsp;V to 2.6&nbsp;V exhibit a significant mid-frequency semicircle, signifying the formation of a CEI film in this voltage range, leading to increased charge transfer resistance. Notably, the impedance in the high-frequency region (R<sub>SEI</sub>) at 4.0&nbsp;V and 3.8&nbsp;V is smaller because the CEI film has not been formed at this voltage. A comparison at 3.6&nbsp;V after 10 cycles, illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b, reveals a substantial semicircle only in the intermediate frequency region of the pre-cycling sample, indicating stabilization of the CEI film in subsequent cycles. The stability of the CEI film is further evidenced by the reduction of R<sub>SEI</sub> from 240&nbsp;ohm to 208&nbsp;ohm after 10 cycles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c display different voltage Nyquist plots of FeHCF-0 and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d presents a comparison of the Nyquist plots for FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 at 3.6&nbsp;V. In contrast to FeHCF-1 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>a), the impedance curve from 3.6&nbsp;V to 2.6&nbsp;V lacks a significant semicircle. This absence is attributed to the pronounced agglomeration of FeHCF-0 <a href="/topics/chemistry/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a>, hindering the formation of a more effective CEI film. Consequently, the cycle stability of FeHCF-0 is notably inferior to that of FeHCF-1 in subsequent cycles </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. To directly observe the disparity in the CEI films between the two, the XPS characterization on samples after 50 cycles were conducted. As illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e, f, the inorganic components within the CEI of FeHCF-1 are significantly higher compared to FeHCF-0. According to prior research, a CEI rich in inorganic constituents exhibits enhanced interfacial stability and migration kinetics, effectively suppressing electrolyte decomposition and thereby improving battery cycling stability <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>. This underscores the superior stability and high diffusion coefficients of FeHCF-1.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr5.jpg" height="390" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (403KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (403KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. The Nyquist plots of FeHCF-1 (a) before cycle and (b) different cycles at 3.6&nbsp;V. (c) The Nyquist plots of FeHCF-0 before cycle. (d) The Nyquist plots at 3.6&nbsp;V of FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1 before cycle. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> results of the sample after 50 cycles, (e) FeHCF-0, (f) FeHCF-1.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0205">To delve into the impact of Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>-assisted synthesis on FeHCF's structure in the room-temperature coprecipitation method, we disassembled batteries following 100 cycles at a current density of 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> to retrieve the cycled cathode electrode. This electrode underwent analysis through SEM, HRTEM, and XRD techniques. Observing <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>a, the cycled cathode electrode displays a smooth surface, free from cracks or <a href="/topics/materials-science/delamination" title="Learn more about delamination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">delamination</a>. Notably, even after 100 cycles (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>b), the <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> in FeHCF-1 maintained their small, uniform morphology. Comparison with the pre-cycle morphology (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>c) reveals minimal change in FeHCF-1, indicating its stable <a href="/topics/chemistry/nanomaterial" title="Learn more about nanostructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanostructure</a>. Examining the XRD peaks of the FeHCF-1 electrode post-100 cycles (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c) against those pre-cycle. The similarity suggests an undamaged crystal structure during charge–discharge cycles. This result further proves that the reduction of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancies makes the crystal structure of FeHCF less susceptible to damage and improves cycle stability. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d–f present HRTEM images of FeHCF-1 after 100 cycles, discharged to 2.0&nbsp;V. Notably, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d exhibits clear lattice stripes across a large area. Fourier transform analysis within the inset of According to the Fourier transform results in inset of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d, the crystal band axis of the sample is [1&nbsp;−1&nbsp;−1], and the lattice spacing of 0.37&nbsp;nm and 0.36&nbsp;nm in the figure can be indexed to the (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;0) crystal planes. In accordance with formula <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-4-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math is="true">2</mn></msup><mo is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">w</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-4"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">d</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><mo stretchy="false" is="true">/</mo><msqrt is="true"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">u</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mo is="true">+</mo><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mo is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">w</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow></msqrt></mrow></math></script></span><span> (a is half of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice parameter from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameter</a><span>, d is the crystal plane spacing, u, v, and are the crystal band axis coefficients), the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/lattice-parameter" title="Learn more about lattice parameter from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameter</a> of the FeHCF-1 crystal after 100 cycles and discharged to 2.0&nbsp;V is 1.0465&nbsp;nm, which is slightly higher than the 1.0199&nbsp;nm before the cycle. This expansion primarily results from Na</span></span><sup>+</sup> entering the lattice gap during discharge, nearly filling it by the 2.0&nbsp;V discharge and causing a slight lattice expansion. The magnified view of lattice fringes and the crystal structure model of sample FeHCF-1 in the [1&nbsp;−1&nbsp;−1] perspective is presented in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>e. This illustration indicates the structural stability and symmetry of the sample during cycling, thereby providing additional evidence for the enhanced robustness of the FeHCF structure achieved through the reduction of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> defects. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>f reveals the existence of Na<sup>+</sup> storage channels within the lattice stripes, creating favorable conditions for Na<sup>+</sup> transport. Notably, local magnification highlights the periodic absence of lattice stripes in certain regions, signifying potential vulnerability in specific areas of the sample lattice during cycling. The HRTEM images of the sample FeHCF-1 after 100 cycles at charging to 4.0&nbsp;V are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>g-i. The crystal band axis of the sample is [0&nbsp;1&nbsp;−1], and the lattice spacing of 0.27&nbsp;nm and 0.36&nbsp;nm can be indexed to (2&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) and (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;0) crystal planes (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>g). At 4.0&nbsp;V, the sample is sodium-poor structure, and the <a href="/topics/chemistry/lattice-parameter" title="Learn more about lattice parameter from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameter</a> of the sample is calculated to be 1.0491&nbsp;nm, which is similar to the 2.0&nbsp;V sodium-rich structure. This shows that after the cycle, even if Na</span><sup>+</sup> in the sample are removed from the lattice, the lattice of the sample will not be completely restored to the size of the non-cycle. The local magnification of the lattice stripes and the crystal structure model of the sample FeHCF-1 from the perspective of [1&nbsp;−1&nbsp;−1] are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>h. The lattice stripes in some areas of the sample are still regular, indicating that the lattice structure of the sample has a certain resistance to the deintercalation of Na<sup>+</sup>. In addition, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>i shows that the lattice stripes of some areas are messy, which further indicates that although the structure of the sample is stronger, partial damage will occur in some areas where defects are more concentrated.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr6.jpg" height="485" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (494KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (494KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0050"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. <span>(a,b) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about SEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEM</a><span> image of FeHCF-1 after 100 cycles. (c) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> pattern of FeHCF-1 before cycle and after 100 cycles. </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/tem-image" title="Learn more about HRTEM image from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM image</a> and the crystal structure model of FeHCF-1 after 100 cycles (d-f) at discharging to 2.0&nbsp;V and (g–i) charging to 4.0&nbsp;V.</p></span></span></figure></div></section></section><section id="s0045"><h2 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0210">In summary, we employed a room-temperature coprecipitation method, building upon the introduction of a chelating agent, to modulate FeHCF of our system by incorporating sodium salts. This strategic approach successfully yielded hexacyanoferrate with reduced [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancy defects. The incorporation of sodium salt serves a dual purpose: not only does it enhance the morphology and structure of FeHCF, but it also elevates the sodium content within the structure. The introduction of Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub><span> leads to the formation of sample <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> characterized by a smaller size and uniform morphology. This advantageous configuration facilitates the efficient transport of sodium ions throughout the cycling process. Further investigations demonstrate that the mitigation of [Fe(CN)</span><sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> vacancy defects plays a pivotal role. It amplifies the capacity attributed to the redox of low-spin iron, augments the diffusion rate of sodium ions, and effectively fortifies the stability of the FeHCF cyclic structure. Additionally, CV measurements confirm the intercalation pseudocapacitive behavior of sodium ions induced by the low-spin iron <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a>, elucidating the notable increase in sodium ion diffusion coefficient at this voltage. The discharge capacity of the sample, augmented with Na</span><sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, reaches an impressive 130.8 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> in the initial cycle. Notably, even after 100 cycles, the capacity retention rate stands at 87.4&nbsp;%, surpassing the performance of the sample without sodium salt.</div></section><section id="s0050"><h2 id="st075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0215"><strong>Qinglin Wang:</strong> Writing – original draft, Validation, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>Weilu Wang:</strong> Writing – original draft, Validation, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>Zheng Xing:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Validation, Funding acquisition, Formal analysis, Conceptualization. <strong>Yuchen Wu:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Xinran Gao:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Chuanhao Nie:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Runzhu Cui:</strong> Formal analysis. <strong>Zhicheng Ju:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Writing – original draft, Funding acquisition.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0220">The authors declare the following financial interests/personal relationships which may be considered as potential competing interests: Zhicheng Ju reports financial support was provided by National Natural Science Foundation of China. If there are other authors, they declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st085" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0225">This research was supported by the <span id="gp005">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22279162</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21975283</span></span></a>). class="reference" id="h0030"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">M.M. Wanderley, C. Wang, C.D. Wu, W. Lin</div><div id="ref-id-h0030" class="title text-m">A chiral porous metal-organic framework for highly sensitive and enantioselective fluorescence sensing of amino alcohols</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">J. Am. Chem. height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0275" id="ref-id-b0275" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0275"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">A.K. Solarajan, V. Murugadoss, S. Angaiah</div><div id="ref-id-h0275" class="title text-m">Montmorillonite embedded electrospun PVdF–HFP nanocomposite membrane electrolyte for Li-ion capacitors</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Appl. Mater. Nie, X. Zhang, H. Ren, Z. Xing, X. Cao, J. Liu, D. Wei, Z. Ju</div><div id="ref-id-h0280" class="title text-m">Synthesis of manganese-based Prussian blue nanocubes with organic solvent as high-performance anodes for lithium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Eur. J. Inorg. Chem., 2019 (28) (2019), pp. 3277-3286, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/ejic.201900458" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10.1002/ejic.201900458</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85068937132&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Synthesis%20of%20manganese-based%20Prussian%20blue%20nanocubes%20with%20organic%20solvent%20as%20high-performance%20anodes%20for%20lithium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2019&amp;author=C.%20Nie&amp;author=X.%20Zhang&amp;author=H.%20Ren&amp;author=Z.%20Xing&amp;author=X.%20Cao&amp;author=J.%20Liu&amp;author=D.%20Wei&amp;author=Z.%20Ju" 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0285" id="ref-id-b0285" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0285"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">E. Li, X. Tang, J. Zhou, H. Zhao, J. Teng, J. Huang, B. Dai, T. Lu, Q. Tao, K. Zhang, W. Deng, J. Li</div><div id="ref-id-h0285" class="title text-m">Double additive electrolyte solvation engineering to achieve long cycle and high capacity sodium-ion battery</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Chem. Eng. J., 489 (2024), <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cej.2024.151525" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10.1016/j.cej.2024.151525</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Double%20additive%20electrolyte%20solvation%20engineering%20to%20achieve%20long%20cycle%20and%20high%20capacity%20sodium-ion%20battery&amp;publication_year=2024&amp;author=E.%20Li&amp;author=X.%20Tang&amp;author=J.%20Zhou&amp;author=H.%20Zhao&amp;author=J.%20Teng&amp;author=J.%20Huang&amp;author=B.%20Dai&amp;author=T.%20Lu&amp;author=Q.%20Tao&amp;author=K.%20Zhang&amp;author=W.%20Deng&amp;author=J.%20Li" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-h0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (15)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0927775725005928"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A highly efficient chelating agent assisted the synthesis of Prussian blue analogues as a cathode material for sodium ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Colloids and Surfaces A: Physicochemical and Engineering Aspects</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0070">Prussian blue analog (PBA) is a common cathode material in sodium-ion batteries, which has the advantages of low synthesis price and high theoretical capacity. However, too fast reaction during its synthesis process can cause its lattice defects, which can negatively affect the cycling performance and rate performance of the battery. Here we developed a new chelating agent for Prussian blue synthesis, and investigate the effects of crystal shape as well as elemental content on the electrochemical properties of prussian blue. It is found that with the increase of cysteine usage, the Fe<sup>2+</sup> content in prussian blue gradually increased, the Na<sup>+</sup> content increased accordingly, and the interstitial water content within the crystal decreased, the prepared PB-75 sample reaches a discharge capacity of 149.13 mA h g<sup>−1</sup> at a current density of 50 mA g<sup>−1</sup>. After cycling for 500 times at a high rate of 500 mA g<sup>−1</sup>, it maintains 78.34 % of the capacity. Compared to sodium citrate, the quantity of cysteine has been significantly reduced, while still achieving favorable electrochemical properties. The findings indicate that cysteine serves as an efficient chelating agent in the synthesis of low-cost, high-capacity, and long-cycle-life sodium cathode materials.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1383586624045817"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Construction of low-vacancy hexagonal Prussian blue analogues for efficient rubidium recovery</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Separation and Purification Technology</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) are considered a promising adsorbent for rubidium recovery due to their high ion exchange capacity and selectivity. However, the development of PBAs-based rubidium adsorbents with excellent stability and adsorption capacity is still hindered by the inevitable CN ligand vacancies. Herein, a synthetic strategy is proposed to slow down crystal nucleation and promote the self-repair of crystal defects by incorporating N-doped porous carbon (NPC) as a solid modifier during the synthesis process. As a result, the vacancy content of Zn-PBA-NPC is significantly decreased and large size twinned crystals are produced, which remarkably improves the thermal and acid-base stability. Benefiting from the high content of K<sup>+</sup> in the low-vacancy Zn-PBA-NPC, it achieves a high adsorption amount of 199.1&nbsp;mg g<sup>−1</sup> and rapid adsorption kinetics of just 5&nbsp;min for Rb<sup>+</sup>. In addition, it shows good selectivity in the presence of other alkali metal ions. This work not only prepares a high-performance adsorbent for efficient recovery of Rb<sup>+</sup>, but also facilitates insights into the design and construction of low-vacancy PBAs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775325007025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Thermally activated prussian blue analogues low-spin iron for enhanced sodium ion storage performance</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Power Sources</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Iron-based Prussian Blue Analogues (PBAs) are widely utilized in sodium-ion battery cathodes owing to their low cost and high theoretical capacity (170 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>). However, the electrochemical inactivity of low-spin iron (LS-Fe) significantly limits the operating voltage and capacity, thereby hindering the energy density of the battery. This study introduces a method for thermally activating the LS-Fe capacity of Prussian Blue Analogues under a nitrogen atmosphere. The results show that the LS-Fe capacity increases progressively with temperature. However, excessively high temperatures can lead to decomposition and oxide formation, which subsequently reduces the capacity. The sample thermally activated at 200&nbsp;°C (PB-200) demonstrates the highest specific capacity of 119.86 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.2C and optimal rate performance. Moreover, after 500 cycles at 5C, PB-200 retains 84.6&nbsp;% of its initial capacity. In-situ Electrochemical Impedance Spectroscopy (EIS) and Galvanostatic Intermittent Titration Technique (GITT) measurements reveal a significant improvement in the diffusion process following heat treatment, attributed to phase changes during heating, resulting in lattice misalignment and crack formation. The full cell exhibits a stable capacity of 84.81 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.2C. After 100 cycles at 1C, its capacity remains at 70.7&nbsp;%.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324014666"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Modified multi-metal Prussian blue analogues toward high-performance cathode for sodium-ion battery</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Power Sources</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">To enhance the electrochemical performance of PBAs, various methods have been proposed to mitigate the adverse effects of water content and structural defects by slowing down the crystallization rate. The introduction of a chelating agent during co-precipitation can produce PBA with a higher Na content, and minimal vacancy defects and water for improving SIB performance [14–16]. For example, Cao et al. prepared PBA with low structural defects by using sodium citrate as chelating agent [17].</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Increasing demand for energy storage devices coupled with lithium precursor shortage opens up a new opportunity for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) to be considered as a replacement of lithium-ion batteries to become a new generation of energy storage device for commercial application. Prussian blue analogue (PBA) demonstrates great advantages as the cathodes for SIB owing to its simple synthesis method, inexpensive raw materials, and high theoretical specific capacity. Single phase multi-metal based PBA of Na<sub>1.92</sub>(Mn<sub>0.3</sub>Fe<sub>0.23</sub>Co<sub>0.3</sub>Ni<sub>0.17</sub>)[Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.88</sub>⋅2.16H<sub>2</sub>O with low contents of crystal water and [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4–</sup>defects was obtained by controlling the nucleation reaction rate via using sodium citrate as a chelating agent, and the assistance of N<sub>2</sub> as an antioxidant and a protective gas. The obtained PBA with high purity and high crystallinity delivers a specific capacity of 120 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, excellent rate capability, and impressive cycling performance with 82&nbsp;% capacity retention after 1000 cycles.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1385894724079713"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Zinc hexacyanoferrate with open framework for efficient aqueous cobalt ions storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Chemical Engineering Journal</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-4-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-4" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">In this work, we report a high-performance aqueous Co-ion battery with zinc hexacyanoferrate as Co<sup>2+</sup> storage material. Owing to the open framework, zinc hexacyanoferrate exhibits excellent electrochemical performance. The reversible capacity of zinc hexacyanoferrate is up to 62.4 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 5C with ultralow capacity decay (0.0084&nbsp;% per cycle) within 500 cycles. Even cycled at a higher rate of 10C, zinc hexacyanoferrate still can remain a high capacity retention of 98.8&nbsp;% after 700 cycles. The excellent electrochemical performance is attributed to the rapid kinetics behavior of Co<sup>2+</sup> in the open and stable framework structure. Besides, a joint analysis of in-situ X-ray diffraction, ex-situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy and ex-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy verifies the highly reversible structural change of zinc hexacyanoferrate during charge/discharge process. All these evidences suggest that zinc hexacyanoferrate may be a promising host material for Co<sup>2+</sup> storage in aqueous rechargeable batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.nanolett.4c03985" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">In Situ Balanced Synthesis of High-Activity Low-Spin Iron Cathode Prussian Blue for Enhanced Sodium-Ion Storage</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Nano Letters</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li></ul><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-secondary large-alternative button-alternative-icon-left"     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {

    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>

      <script data-cfasync="false">
      (function initOneTrust()  {
        const monitor = {
  init: () => {},
  loaded: () => {},
};
        function enableGroup(group) {
  document.querySelectorAll(`script[type*="ot-${group}"]`).forEach(script => {
    script.type = 'text/javascript';
    document.head.appendChild(script);
  });
}
        function runOneTrustCookies(doClear, monitor) {
  const oneTrustConsentSdkId = 'onetrust-consent-sdk';
  const emptyNodeSelectors = 'h3.ot-host-name, h4.ot-host-desc, button.ot-host-box';
  const ariaLabelledByButtonNodes = 'div.ot-accordion-layout > button';
  const ariaAttribute = 'aria-labelledby';
  function adjustOneTrustDOM() {
    const oneTrustRoot = document.getElementById('onetrust-consent-sdk');

    /* remove empty nodes */
    [...(oneTrustRoot?.querySelectorAll(emptyNodeSelectors) ?? [])].filter(e => e.textContent === '').forEach(e => e.remove());

    /* remove invalid aria-labelledby values */
    oneTrustRoot?.querySelectorAll(ariaLabelledByButtonNodes).forEach(e => {
      const presentIdValue = e.getAttribute(ariaAttribute)?.split(' ').filter(label => document.getElementById(label)).join(' ');
      if (presentIdValue) {
        e.setAttribute(ariaAttribute, presentIdValue);
      }
    });
  }
  function observeOneTrustLoaded(shouldSetOTDefaults, isConsentPresent) {
    const cb = (mutationList, observer) => {
      const oneTrustRoot = mutationList.filter(mutationRecord => mutationRecord.type === 'childList' && mutationRecord.addedNodes.length).map(mutationRecord => [...mutationRecord.addedNodes]).flat().find(e => e.id === oneTrustConsentSdkId);
      if (oneTrustRoot && typeof OneTrust !== 'undefined') {
        monitor.loaded(true);
        OneTrust.OnConsentChanged(() => {
          const perfAllowed = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie.match('(^| )OptanonConsent=([^;]+)')?.[2])?.match('groups=([0-9:0|1,?]+)&?')?.[1]?.match('2:([0|1])')[1] === '1';
          if (perfAllowed) {
            enableGroup('performance');
          }
        });
        if (!isConsentPresent && (shouldSetOTDefaults || OneTrust.GetDomainData().ConsentModel.Name === 'implied consent')) {
          OneTrust.UpdateConsent(`Category`, `1:1`);
          OneTrust.UpdateConsent(`Category`, `2:1`);
          OneTrust.UpdateConsent(`Category`, `3:1`);
          OneTrust.UpdateConsent(`Category`, `4:0`);
        }
        document.dispatchEvent(new CustomEvent('@sdtech/onetrust/loaded', {}));
        observer.disconnect();
        adjustOneTrustDOM();
      }
    };
    const observer = new MutationObserver(cb);
    observer.observe(document.querySelector('body'), {
      childList: true
    });
  }
  if (doClear) {
    document.cookie = 'OptanonAlertBoxClosed=; expires=Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 UTC; samesite=lax; path=/';
  }
  const isConsentPresent = !!decodeURIComponent(document.cookie.match('(^| )OptanonConsent=([^;]+)')?.[2])?.match('groups=([0-9:0|1,?]+)&?')?.[1];
  const shouldSetOTDefaults = 'false' === 'false' && !document.cookie?.match('OptanonAlertBoxClosed=');
  if (shouldSetOTDefaults) {
    const date = new Date();
    date.setFullYear(date.getFullYear() + 1);
    document.cookie = `OptanonAlertBoxClosed=${new Date().toISOString()}; expires=${date.toUTCString()}; samesite=lax; path=/; domain=sciencedirect.com`;
  }
  observeOneTrustLoaded(shouldSetOTDefaults, isConsentPresent, monitor);
  window.addOTScript = () => {
    const otSDK = document.createElement('script');
    otSDK.setAttribute('data-cfasync', 'false');
    otSDK.setAttribute('src', 'https://cdn.cookielaw.org/scripttemplates/otSDKStub.js');
    otSDK.setAttribute('data-document-language', 'true');
    otSDK.setAttribute('data-domain-script', '865ea198-88cc-4e41-8952-1df75d554d02');
    window.addOTScript = () => {};
    document.head.appendChild(otSDK);
    monitor.init();
  };
  window.addEventListener('load', () => window.addOTScript());
}
        if (document.location.host.match(/.sciencedirect.com$/)) {
          runOneTrustCookies(true, monitor);
        }
        else {
          window.addEventListener('load', (event) => {
            enableGroup('performance');
          });
        }
      }());
    </script>
