The microstructure of the samples after 100 cycles was analyzed by field emission <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F20, FEI). The accurate quantification of elements is obtained by inductively </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/inductively-coupled-plasma" title="Learn more about inductively coupled plasma from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inductively coupled plasma</a> (ICP, Thermo Fisher iCAP PRO).</span></div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span><span><span>The FeHCF active material, <a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-nanotube" title="Learn more about carbon nanotubes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon nanotubes</a> (CNTs), and </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/polyvinylidene-fluoride" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene fluoride from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene fluoride</a><span><span> (PVDF) were mixed in N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) at a mass ratio of 7:2:1. The electrode paste was obtained by mechanical <a href="/topics/chemistry/ball-milling" title="Learn more about ball milling from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ball milling</a>, then the paste was coated on </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/aluminum" title="Learn more about aluminum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminum</a> foil, and the </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/working-electrode" title="Learn more about working electrode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">working electrode</a> was obtained by vacuum drying at 120&nbsp;°C for 20&nbsp;h, its mass loading is about 1.02&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span><sup>−2</sup><span>. The working electrode was used as the cathode, sodium metal was used as the anode, the <a href="/topics/chemistry/glass-fiber" title="Learn more about glass fiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glass fiber</a> filter paper of Whatman GF/D was used as the separator, and the mixed solvent of 1&nbsp;mol/L NaClO</span><sub>4</sub><span><span><span> of ethylene carbonate (EC) and <a href="/topics/chemistry/propene" title="Learn more about propylene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">propylene</a> carbonate (PC) (vol/vol&nbsp;=&nbsp;1:1) with 5&nbsp;vol% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as electrolyte. They were assembled in the argon-filled glove box to assemble 2032 type coin cells. Galvanostatic charge/discharge tests are tested by the LAND testing system in the voltage window of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V. The galvanostatic intermittent </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about titration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">titration</a> technique (GITT) tests were performed using the LAND testing system to measure the chemical </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a><span> of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a>. A current pulse of 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g</span></span><sup>−1</sup> was applied for 5&nbsp;min, then left to stand for 30&nbsp;min, and then cycled to the set voltage following the two steps above. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests were performed using the electrochemical workstation (CHI660e) with the scanning voltage range of 2–4&nbsp;V at the scanning rate of 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup><span>. <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) was performed on the CHI660e electrochemical workstation. The frequency is set between 0.01&nbsp;Hz and 100&nbsp;kHz. All electrochemical tests were performed at room temperature.</span></div></section></section><section id="s0030"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="s0035"><h3 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Morphology and structure</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">Due to the rapid nucleation rate, PBAs synthesized through the room-temperature coprecipitation method often exhibit an increased presence of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancies in their crystal structure. This study explores the influence of various sodium salts on the lattice structure and morphology of PBAs using the room-temperature coprecipitation method, in conjunction with a chelating agent. The crystal structure of samples, synthesized with and without the addition of different sodium salts, was characterized using powder XRD (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>a). All diffraction peaks for FeHCF-0, FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3 are consistent, signifying identical crystal structures. These peaks correspond to the face-centered cubic structure of PBAs with the Fm-3&nbsp;m space group (JCPDS No. 52-1907, a&nbsp;=&nbsp;b&nbsp;=&nbsp;c&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.0199&nbsp;nm) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>. Notably, XRD patterns reveal that these samples maintain a typical cubic phase, and the introduction of sodium salts does not induce any phase transitions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a><span>. Furthermore, diffraction peaks for FeHCF-0, FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3 exhibit sharpness, indicating good <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a><span>. The addition of sodium salts (FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3) results in even narrower and sharper peaks compared to the sample without sodium salts (FeHCF-0). Suggesting an enhanced <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a> when sodium salts are incorporated in the room-temperature coprecipitation method. However, when using EDTA-2Na as the sodium salt, sample FeHCF-4 displays additional impurity peaks (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>a), indicating the generation of other impurity phases during the synthesis process. To explore the impact of various sodium salts on sample morphology in the room-temperature coprecipitation method, all samples were characterized by SEM. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b, FeHCF-0, synthesized without sodium salt, exhibits small particles and severe agglomeration due to rapid precipitation and nucleation. This is a hindrance to sodium ion insertion/extraction during charge and discharge <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>. FeHCF-1, synthesized with Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub><span> assistance, demonstrates uniform-sized <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> with excellent dispersion (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>c). Its <a href="/topics/materials-science/particle-size-analysis" title="Learn more about particle size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">particle size distribution</a>, about 45.2&nbsp;nm (inset in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c), favors shorter sodium ion diffusion paths, enhancing electrode–electrolyte contact and facilitating sodium ion transport. The morphology of FeHCF-2 assisted by the addition of sodium citrate is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>d. Due to sodium citrate chelation of Fe<sup>2+</sup>, slowing Fe<sup>2+</sup> release when mixed with Na<sub>4</sub>Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub> solution (solution A). FeHCF-2, assisted by sodium citrate addition, exhibits cubic morphology with distinct edges and uniform particle size <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>. FeHCF-3, synthesized with NaCl addition, displays significant nanoparticle agglomeration (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>e). Meanwhile, FeHCF-4, assisted by EDTA-2Na addition, comprises rod-like structures, 5–15&nbsp;μm in length (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>b), differing notably from other samples. Which confirming to XRD findings. SEM patterns reveal that adding sodium salts, particularly Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, in the room-temperature coprecipitation method effectively mitigates PBAs nanoparticle agglomeration. Moreover, he element distribution and content analysis of elements Na and Fe on the surface of the samples were measured by EDS. EDS results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a><span>) showcase uniform distribution of Na and Fe elements in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a>. From the element ratios in the EDS results of the samples with the addition of different sodium salts, it can be proved that the addition of sodium salts can increase the sodium content in the obtained PBAs to different degrees.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr1.jpg" height="548" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (509KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (509KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span><span>(a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns of all samples. (b–e) </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about SEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEM</a> image of the samples, (b) FeHCF-0, (c) FeHCF-1, (d) FeHCF-2, (e) FeHCF-3. (f) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a><span> patterns image of FeHCF-1. (g, h) <a href="/topics/chemistry/tem-image" title="Learn more about HRTEM images from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM images</a> of FeHCF-1. (i) The crystal structure model of FeHCF-1.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070">High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) measurements were used to further study the crystal structure of FeHCF-1 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>f–h). The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structure-of-solids" title="Learn more about solid structure of from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid structure of</a> the sample FeHCF-1 can be seen from </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a><span>, which shows that the sample is a uniformly distributed solid structure. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a> patterns in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>f is the shows that the sample is <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/polycrystal" title="Learn more about polycrystal from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polycrystal</a>, and correspond to the crystal faces of (1</span>&nbsp;0&nbsp;0), (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;0), (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;1), and (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;0). The HRTEM image of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>g shows clear lattice fringes. The lattice spacings of 0.40&nbsp;nm, 0.41&nbsp;nm and 0.53&nbsp;nm can be indexed to the (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;1), (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;1) and (2&nbsp;0&nbsp;<span>0) crystal faces of PBAs. This can be verified from the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a><span> patterns obtained through <a href="/topics/chemistry/fourier-transform" title="Learn more about Fourier transform from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fourier transform</a> in the inset of </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>g. In addition, a partial enlarged view of the lattice fringes (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>h) and the crystal structure model of the sample FeHCF-1 view at [0&nbsp;1&nbsp;−2] (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>i) is depicted for convenient visualization.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075"><span>FTIR, TGA, XPS, and <a href="/topics/chemistry/inductively-coupled-plasma" title="Learn more about ICP from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ICP</a><span> were utilized to determine the chemical <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composition</a><span> and offer a quantitative description of the sample constituents. FTIR provides essential functional group information, aiding in the identification of the <a href="/topics/chemistry/chemical-substance-type" title="Learn more about material's chemical from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">material's chemical</a> composition. In </span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>, with the exception of sample FeHCF-4, the absorption peak positions for the other samples align. Suggesting similar structural compositions, consistent with the XRD findings. FeHCF-0, FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3 exhibit robust absorption peaks at 2071&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup><span>, arising from the <a href="/topics/chemistry/stretching-vibration" title="Learn more about stretching vibration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">stretching vibration</a> of </span><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/tbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="triple bond">N coordinated to Fe<sup>II</sup>—a characteristic feature of PBAs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>. Notably, no discernible absorption peaks appear in regions with slightly higher binding energy, indicating exclusive coordination between Fe<sup>II</sup> and <img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/tbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="triple bond">N, with minimal coordination between Fe<sup>III</sup> and <img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/tbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="triple bond">N <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>. Furthermore, the absorption peak at 1610&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup><span> corresponds to the <a href="/topics/chemistry/bending-vibration" title="Learn more about bending vibration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">bending vibration</a> of O</span><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond"><span>H, affirming the presence of water in the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystal-lattice" title="Learn more about crystal lattice from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystal lattice</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>. Additionally, a minor absorption peak around 1000&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> is observed in both FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-2, indicative of various chemical environments associated with C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">O bonds <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>. This can be attributed to the presence of crystalline water and residual citrate ions in FeHCF-2.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr2.jpg" height="511" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (563KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (563KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>(a) FTIR spectra of all samples. (b) <a href="/topics/chemistry/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about TGA from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TGA</a> curves. (c) Wide-scan </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectrum. (d) High-resolution spectra of Fe 2p XPS spectrum of the sample FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">To assess water content in samples synthesized via the room-temperature coprecipitation method, TGA tests were conducted on FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1, with results depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span><span><span>b. FeHCF-1 exhibits negligible weight loss up to 100&nbsp;°C, suggesting removal of adsorbed water during material preparation. Conversely, FeHCF-0 shows significant weight loss before 100&nbsp;°C, attributed to increased <a href="/topics/materials-science/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> enhancing its adsorption capacity and accumulating </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/surface-water" title="Learn more about surface water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface water</a> during synthesis. At 200&nbsp;°C, FeHCF-1 experiences a 6.5&nbsp;% weight loss, while FeHCF-0 undergoes a 23.2&nbsp;% loss, attributable to </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/interstitial-water" title="Learn more about interstitial water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interstitial water</a> evaporation in the lattice structure. Between 200&nbsp;°C and 260&nbsp;°C, FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 register 8.5&nbsp;% and 5.6&nbsp;% weight losses, respectively, linked to coordinated water elimination. Above 260&nbsp;°C, samples weight losses are ascribed to cyano decomposition in the PBAs </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>. Consequently, water content is determined to be 28.8&nbsp;wt% in FeHCF-0 and 15.0&nbsp;wt% in FeHCF-1.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">The elemental composition of samples FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1, along with the valence state of transition metal Fe, was determined using XPS. Analysis of the wide-scan XPS spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c) reveals that both FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1 comprise elements C, N, O, Fe, and Na. In the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Fe 2p (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d), distinctive peaks at 708.7 and 721.6&nbsp;eV correspond to Fe<sup>II</sup>2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Fe<sup>II</sup>2p<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively. Additionally, weaker peaks at 712.8 and 724.7&nbsp;eV are associated with Fe<sup>III</sup>2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Fe<sup>III</sup>2p<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a><span>. The XPS findings indicate that a fraction of ferrous iron in the synthesized FeHCF-1 underwent <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> to ferric iron during the room-temperature coprecipitation process. Calculation of the shadow area ratio from XPS data (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>) provided the Fe<sup>II</sup> to Fe<sup>III</sup> ratio, which exhibited no significant change. However, the Na/Fe ratio in FeHCF-1 (1.07) notably surpassed that in FeHCF-0 (0.43), suggesting that introducing Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> during PBA synthesis via room-temperature coprecipitation substantially increased sodium content, as evidenced by the ICP results in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a>. Consequently, the role and positioning of iron in the crystal structure underwent evident alterations, effectively enhancing the sample's structure. Based on TGA, XPS, and ICP results, the structural formula for FeHCF-0 is Na<sub>0.43</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.26</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.29</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.45</sub>□<sub>0.10</sub>·3.06H<sub>2</sub>O, and that of FeHCF-1 is Na<sub>1.07</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.30</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.14</sub>□<sub>0.12</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>·1.65H<sub>2</sub>O. Analysis of these formulas reveals that the vacancy defect in FeHCF-0 involves [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span>, with a ratio of <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystal-vacancy" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> to node sites at 0.18, while FeHCF-1 exhibits vacancies in the form of Fe, with a ratio of 0.21. Although the introduction of Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> did not decrease the sample's <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a>, it did facilitate the conversion of larger [Fe(CN)</span><sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> vacancies into smaller Fe vacancies. This transformation led to a reduction in total vacancy volume, thereby enhancing the specific capacity and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> of the samples.</span></div></section><section id="s0040"><h3 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Electrochemistry performance</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090"><span>To investigate the impact of sodium salt addition on the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of synthesized FeHCF, galvanostatic charge–discharge tests were conducted across all samples within a voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>a illustrates the cycle performances of various samples at a <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g</span><sup>−1</sup>. The specific capacity of samples FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3 markedly surpasses that of sample FeHCF-0. In particular, the initial cycle discharge capacity of FeHCF-1, synthesized with the addition of Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, reaches 130.8&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. Even after 100 cycles, the discharge capacity remains at 114.3&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, resulting in an impressive capacity retention rate of 87.4&nbsp;%. In contrast, FeHCF-0, synthesized without sodium salt, exhibits a modest initial discharge capacity of 82&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, decreasing to 58.3&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles, with a capacity retention rate of only 71&nbsp;%. Additionally, the capacity retention rates for FeHCF-2, FeHCF-3, and FeHCF-4 are 67&nbsp;%, 58.4&nbsp;%, and 73.3&nbsp;%, respectively. The addition of sodium salt significantly enhances the specific discharge capacity of FeHCF. Certain sodium salts, such as Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, also contribute to the improved cycling stability of FeHCF synthesized through the room-temperature coprecipitation method. Notably, the cycles of FeHCF-1 exhibit no discernible polarization, indicating superior reversibility during the charging/discharging process. The charge/discharge voltage curves for FeHCF-1 at different cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>b) reveal two distinct charge/discharge voltage plateaus. The higher voltage plateau corresponds to the <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> of low-spin iron associated with C atoms in Na</span><sub>x</sub>Fe [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub><span>], while the lower voltage plateau corresponds to the <a href="/topics/chemistry/redox-reactions" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> of high-spin iron linked to N atoms in Na</span><sub>x</sub>Fe [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]. Despite the chemical formula indicating a higher quantity of low-spin iron in FeHCF-1, the redox activity of high-spin iron surpasses that of low-spin iron. Consequently, the contribution to capacity by the high-voltage plateau corresponding to low-spin iron is considerably lower than that contributed by the low-voltage plateau associated with high-spin iron.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr3.jpg" height="406" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (501KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (501KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a)Cycling performances of all samples. (b) The charge–discharge voltage plateau curves of FeHCF-1 at different cycles. (c) The charge–discharge voltage plateau curves of all samples in the first cycle. <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of the sample (d) FeHCF-1 and (e) FeHCF-0. (f) Rate performance of all samples.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c illustrates the charge–discharge voltage plateau curves for various samples during the initial cycle. It is evident that the first charge capacity of FeHCF-0 is the lowest, measuring only 45&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. This deficiency can be attributed to the low Na<sup>+</sup> content in FeHCF-0. Conversely, the first charge capacities of other samples surpass that of FeHCF-0. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>f establishes a positive correlation between the first charge capacity and the Na<sup>+</sup> content in the samples, affirming that the introduction of Na<sup>+</sup> significantly enhances the initial charge capacity. Despite the higher first charge capacities observed in samples synthesized with sodium salt assistance compared to FeHCF-0, the initial charge capacity for all samples remains relatively low. This is ascribed to the inherently lower sodium content in cubic FeHCF, aligning with findings from XRD pattern analysis <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>. However, during the initial discharging phase, the sodium metal anode serves as a sodium source, facilitating the embedding of more sodium ions into the material's lattice structure. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that FeHCF-0, synthesized without sodium salt assistance, exhibits nearly no discharge voltage platform at high voltage. While samples FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3 showcase stable discharge platforms at high voltage. This discrepancy implies a higher occurrence of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancies in the room-temperature coprecipitation-synthesized FeHCF-0. The addition of sodium salts during synthesis proves effective in mitigating the generation of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> vacancies. This reduction in vacancy defects proves advantageous, enhancing the crystal structure stability of FeHCF and augmenting the diffusion kinetics of sodium ions. The capacity enhancement resulting from the low-spin iron redox reaction confers two notable benefits. Firstly, it effectively mitigates the substantial deintercalation of sodium ions during the high-spin iron redox reaction, thereby alleviating crystal structural stress and improving the cycling stability of the material. Secondly, it contributes to an overall increase in the <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a><span> of the <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e present the CV curves for samples FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 over the initial five cycles within the voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V, employing a scan speed of 0.2&nbsp;mV S<sup>−1</sup>. Commencing from the third cycle, a pronounced alignment in the CV curves is evident, signifying the commendable reversibility of FeHCF-1 during cycling. Furthermore, the CV curves exhibit two discernible pairs of oxidation/reduction peaks at 3.0&nbsp;V/2.6&nbsp;V and 3.6&nbsp;V/3.25&nbsp;V. These peaks correspond to the redox reactions involving high-spin iron and low-spin iron, respectively. This observation aligns with the positions of the dual discharge plateaus discernible in the charge–discharge voltage plateau curves across different cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b). Comparative analysis with the CV curves of FeHCF-0 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e), synthesized without sodium salt-assisted methods, reveals a notably heightened intensity of the redox peak at high voltage in FeHCF-1. This enhancement is attributed to the introduction of sodium salts during synthesis, mitigating [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> vacancies and consequently fostering a greater presence of low-spin iron in FeHCF-1. This augmentation significantly contributes to the improved <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> of FeHCF-1, consistent with the charge–discharge voltage plateau curves of diverse samples during the initial cycle (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c). Based on previous studies <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>, the electrode equations governing the initial charging and discharging processes of FeHCF-1 are as follows:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">Low voltage plateau charging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">Na<sub>1.07</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.30</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.14</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.14Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.14e<sup>−</sup></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">High voltage plateau charging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.37</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>III</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56e<sup>−</sup></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">Low voltage plateau discharging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130">Na<sub>0.37</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>III</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">High voltage plateau discharging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>1.37</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0145">And the electrode equations governing the subsequent reversible processes of FeHCF-1 are as follows:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0150">Low voltage plateau charging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0155">Na<sub>1.37</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44e<sup>−</sup></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0160">High voltage plateau charging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0165">Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.37</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>III</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56e<sup>−</sup></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0170">Low voltage plateau discharging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0175">Na<sub>0.37</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>III</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.56e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0180">High voltage plateau discharging:</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0185">Na<sub>0.93</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;0.44e<sup>−</sup>&nbsp;→&nbsp;Na<sub>1.37</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.44</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0190">The rate performance of various samples within the voltage range of 2.0&nbsp;V–4.0&nbsp;V is depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f. At current densities of 20, 50, 100, 200, and 500&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, the discharge capacities of FeHCF-1 are 104, 93.4, 83.5, 72.4, and 59.9&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively—significantly surpassing those of FeHCF-0. Specifically, at a current density of 500&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, FeHCF-0 exhibits a discharge capacity of only 48.9&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, whereas FeHCF-1 demonstrates outstanding rate performance. Upon restoring the current density of FeHCF-1 to 20&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, the capacity rebounds to 89.1&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, which indicates that the interface and structure of the sample FeHCF-1 are not damaged under the large current density.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0195"><span>The sodium-storage mechanism and kinetic aspects of the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-reaction" title="Learn more about electrode reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode reaction</a> were investigated through CV measurements of FeHCF-1 under varying scan rates. In </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a, within the voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V for FeHCF-1, the CV curves exhibit minimal distortion as the scan rate increases from 0.1 to 2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup>. Notably, both pairs of redox peaks remain observable, indicating favorable sodium-storage reversibility in FeHCF-1. Analysis of current responses at different scan rates allows the distinction between pseudocapacitive and diffusion-controlled contributions during charge–discharge processes. Calculate the b value according to the formula: <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-3-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi></mrow><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>b</mi></msup></mrow></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="7.196ex" height="2.432ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 3098.3 1047.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.235ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(623,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1679,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-61"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2209,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,362)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-62"></use></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-3"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mo linebreak="goodbreak" linebreakstyle="after" is="true">=</mo><mi is="true">a</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mi is="true">b</mi></msup></mrow></math></script></span><span> (i is the peak current, v is the scan rate, and a is the coefficient). When the b value is close to 1, it indicates that the capacity in the reaction is mainly derived from the pseudocapacitive behavior, while the b value is close to 0.5, indicating that the capacity contributed by the diffusion behavior is dominant in the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> process </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>. Referring to the CV curves of FeHCF-1, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b depicts a linear relationship between log(peak current density, i) and log(scanning rate, v) for oxidation/reduction peaks. The b-values for redox reactions induced by high-spin iron at low voltage are 0.826 and 0.686, signifying that sodium storage in low-voltage, high-spin iron is influenced by both diffusion and pseudocapacitive behaviors <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>. Conversely, b-values for redox reactions induced by low-spin iron at high voltage are 0.897 and 0.893, revealing that sodium storage in high-voltage, low-spin iron is predominantly governed by pseudocapacitive reactions. Taking the discharging process as an illustrative example, we further analyze the sodium-storage mechanism and the rationale for pseudocapacitive behavior in this sample. During the intercalation of sodium ions into the FeHCF framework, sodium ions initially occupy the body-centered position and subsequently migrate to the face-centered position <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>. This process initiates the reduction of low-spin Fe and mirrors the adsorption of sodium ions on the surface in pseudocapacitive behavior. Consequently, sodium intercalation at high voltage manifests as a pseudocapacitive behavior. However, in contrast to conventional pseudocapacitive behavior, the charge storage in this context occurs within the structure, leading to its classification as intercalation pseudocapacitive behavior <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. Subsequently, sodium ions intercalate into vacant body-centered sites, inducing the reduction of high-spin Fe. As a result, the b-value for the reduction peak at low voltage approximates 0.5, emphasizing the predominant diffusion nature of sodium intercalation. The Na<sup>+</sup><span> diffusion characteristics of FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1 during the charging and discharging processes were assessed using <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about GITT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">GITT</a> in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>. Sodium ion diffusion coefficients (D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup>) were calculated following Fick's law <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d illustrate the dynamic relationship between the diffusion rate of sodium ions and voltage during the charging and discharging processes. D<sub>Na</sub><sup>+</sup> exhibits dynamic changes throughout these processes. The diffusion coefficients for both FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1 decrease with increasing voltage during charging and decrease with decreasing voltage during discharging. Notably, the diffusion coefficient of the sample FeHCF-1 increased significantly at 3.43&nbsp;V during the charging process and 3.13&nbsp;V during the discharging process and is significantly higher than that of the sample FeHCF-0. This enhancement is attributed to the prevalence of low-spin iron redox reactions at these voltages in FeHCF-1. The sodium ions, engaged in intercalation pseudocapacitive behavior, become embedded in the crystal structure, markedly enhancing sodium ion transport kinetics. Additionally, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d reveal that the diffusion coefficient of FeHCF-1 consistently exceeds that of FeHCF-0, indicating a swifter Na+ diffusion rate during charging and discharging, this may be attributed to the relatively smaller size of FeHCF-1 particles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>. Consequently, FeHCF-1 demonstrates superior electrochemical performance compared to FeHCF-0 <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr4.jpg" height="419" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (372KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (372KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span>(a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a><span> curves of the sample FeHCF-1 at different scan rates. (b) Linear relationship between log(current) and log(scanning rate) of peaks in the <a href="/topics/chemistry/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of the sample FeHCF-1. Na</span></span><sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficients from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficients</a> of the samples FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 during the (c) charging and (d) discharging process.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0200"><span>To investigate the impact of sodium salt addition on the kinetic process of FeHCF, <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EIS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EIS</a> measurements were conducted on FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 samples. In the Nyquist plot, the prominent semicircle in the high-frequency region corresponding to the interfacial membrane impedance (R</span><sub>SEI</sub>); the middle-frequency semicircle indicative of charge exchange impedance (R<sub>ct</sub><span>); the low-frequency oblique line corresponding to sodium ion transport in the solid-state diffusion process within the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode material</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a, we present varied voltage Nyquist plots of FeHCF-1 synthesized by adding Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> before cycling. Curves ranging from 3.6&nbsp;V to 2.6&nbsp;V exhibit a significant mid-frequency semicircle, signifying the formation of a CEI film in this voltage range, leading to increased charge transfer resistance. Notably, the impedance in the high-frequency region (R<sub>SEI</sub>) at 4.0&nbsp;V and 3.8&nbsp;V is smaller because the CEI film has not been formed at this voltage. A comparison at 3.6&nbsp;V after 10 cycles, illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b, reveals a substantial semicircle only in the intermediate frequency region of the pre-cycling sample, indicating stabilization of the CEI film in subsequent cycles. The stability of the CEI film is further evidenced by the reduction of R<sub>SEI</sub> from 240&nbsp;ohm to 208&nbsp;ohm after 10 cycles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c display different voltage Nyquist plots of FeHCF-0 and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d presents a comparison of the Nyquist plots for FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 at 3.6&nbsp;V. In contrast to FeHCF-1 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>a), the impedance curve from 3.6&nbsp;V to 2.6&nbsp;V lacks a significant semicircle. This absence is attributed to the pronounced agglomeration of FeHCF-0 <a href="/topics/chemistry/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a>, hindering the formation of a more effective CEI film. Consequently, the cycle stability of FeHCF-0 is notably inferior to that of FeHCF-1 in subsequent cycles </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>. To directly observe the disparity in the CEI films between the two, the XPS characterization on samples after 50 cycles were conducted. As illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>e, f, the inorganic components within the CEI of FeHCF-1 are significantly higher compared to FeHCF-0. According to prior research, a CEI rich in inorganic constituents exhibits enhanced interfacial stability and migration kinetics, effectively suppressing electrolyte decomposition and thereby improving battery cycling stability <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>. This underscores the superior stability and high diffusion coefficients of FeHCF-1.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr5.jpg" height="390" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (403KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (403KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0045"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. The Nyquist plots of FeHCF-1 (a) before cycle and (b) different cycles at 3.6&nbsp;V. (c) The Nyquist plots of FeHCF-0 before cycle. (d) The Nyquist plots at 3.6&nbsp;V of FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1 before cycle. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> results of the sample after 50 cycles, (e) FeHCF-0, (f) FeHCF-1.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0205">To delve into the impact of Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>-assisted synthesis on FeHCF's structure in the room-temperature coprecipitation method, we disassembled batteries following 100 cycles at a current density of 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> to retrieve the cycled cathode electrode. This electrode underwent analysis through SEM, HRTEM, and XRD techniques. Observing <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>a, the cycled cathode electrode displays a smooth surface, free from cracks or <a href="/topics/materials-science/delamination" title="Learn more about delamination from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">delamination</a>. Notably, even after 100 cycles (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a><span>b), the <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> in FeHCF-1 maintained their small, uniform morphology. Comparison with the pre-cycle morphology (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>c) reveals minimal change in FeHCF-1, indicating its stable <a href="/topics/chemistry/nanomaterial" title="Learn more about nanostructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanostructure</a>. Examining the XRD peaks of the FeHCF-1 electrode post-100 cycles (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c) against those pre-cycle. The similarity suggests an undamaged crystal structure during charge–discharge cycles. This result further proves that the reduction of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancies makes the crystal structure of FeHCF less susceptible to damage and improves cycle stability. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d–f present HRTEM images of FeHCF-1 after 100 cycles, discharged to 2.0&nbsp;V. Notably, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d exhibits clear lattice stripes across a large area. Fourier transform analysis within the inset of According to the Fourier transform results in inset of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d, the crystal band axis of the sample is [1&nbsp;−1&nbsp;−1], and the lattice spacing of 0.37&nbsp;nm and 0.36&nbsp;nm in the figure can be indexed to the (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;0) crystal planes. In accordance with formula <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-4-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>d</mi><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; linebreakstyle=&quot;after&quot;
