t(G,F,aa,Z,k,H,I){G=K(G,K(K(n(F,aa,Z),k),I));return K(L(G,H),F)}function e(G){var Z;var F=G.length;var x=F+8;var k=(x-(x%64))/64;var I=(k+1)*16;var aa=Array(I-1);var d=0;var H=0;while(H<F){Z=(H-(H%4))/4;d=(H%4)*8;aa[Z]=(aa[Z]| (G.charCodeAt(H)<<d));H++}Z=(H-(H%4))/4;d=(H%4)*8;aa[Z]=aa[Z]|(128<<d);aa[I-2]=F<<3;aa[I-1]=F>>>29;return aa}function B(x){var k="",F="",G,d;for(d=0;d<=3;d++){G=(x>>>(d*8))&255;F="0"+G.toString(16);k=k+F.substr(F.length-2,2)}return k}function J(k){k=k.replace(/rn/g,"n");var d="";for(var F=0;F<k.length;F++){var x=k.charCodeAt(F);if(x<128){d+=String.fromCharCode(x)}else{if((x>127)&&(x<2048)){d+=String.fromCharCode((x>>6)|192);d+=String.fromCharCode((x&63)|128)}else{d+=String.fromCharCode((x>>12)|224);d+=String.fromCharCode(((x>>6)&63)|128);d+=String.fromCharCode((x&63)|128)}}}return d}var C=Array();var P,h,E,v,g,Y,X,W,V;var S=7,Q=12,N=17,M=22;var A=5,z=9,y=14,w=20;var o=4,m=11,l=16,j=23;var U=6,T=10,R=15,O=21;s=J(s);C=e(s);Y=1732584193;X=4023233417;W=2562383102;V=271733878;for(P=0;P<C.length;P+=16){h=Y;E=X;v=W;g=V;Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+0],S,3614090360);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+1],Q,3905402710);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+2],N,606105819);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+3],M,3250441966);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+4],S,4118548399);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+5],Q,1200080426);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+6],N,2821735955);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+7],M,4249261313);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+8],S,1770035416);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+9],Q,2336552879);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+10],N,4294925233);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+11],M,2304563134);Y=u(Y,X,W,V,C[P+12],S,1804603682);V=u(V,Y,X,W,C[P+13],Q,4254626195);W=u(W,V,Y,X,C[P+14],N,2792965006);X=u(X,W,V,Y,C[P+15],M,1236535329);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+1],A,4129170786);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+6],z,3225465664);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+11],y,643717713);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+0],w,3921069994);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+5],A,3593408605);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+10],z,38016083);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+15],y,3634488961);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+4],w,3889429448);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+9],A,568446438);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+14],z,3275163606);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+3],y,4107603335);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+8],w,1163531501);Y=f(Y,X,W,V,C[P+13],A,2850285829);V=f(V,Y,X,W,C[P+2],z,4243563512);W=f(W,V,Y,X,C[P+7],y,1735328473);X=f(X,W,V,Y,C[P+12],w,2368359562);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+5],o,4294588738);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+8],m,2272392833);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+11],l,1839030562);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+14],j,4259657740);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+1],o,2763975236);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+4],m,1272893353);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+7],l,4139469664);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+10],j,3200236656);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+13],o,681279174);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+0],m,3936430074);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+3],l,3572445317);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+6],j,76029189);Y=D(Y,X,W,V,C[P+9],o,3654602809);V=D(V,Y,X,W,C[P+12],m,3873151461);W=D(W,V,Y,X,C[P+15],l,530742520);X=D(X,W,V,Y,C[P+2],j,3299628645);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+0],U,4096336452);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+7],T,1126891415);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+14],R,2878612391);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+5],O,4237533241);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+12],U,1700485571);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+3],T,2399980690);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+10],R,4293915773);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+1],O,2240044497);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+8],U,1873313359);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+15],T,4264355552);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+6],R,2734768916);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+13],O,1309151649);Y=t(Y,X,W,V,C[P+4],U,4149444226);V=t(V,Y,X,W,C[P+11],T,3174756917);W=t(W,V,Y,X,C[P+2],R,718787259);X=t(X,W,V,Y,C[P+9],O,3951481745);Y=K(Y,h);X=K(X,E);W=K(W,v);V=K(V,g)}var i=B(Y)+B(X)+B(W)+B(V);return i.toLowerCase()}
    ,stripProductDelimiters: function(val) {
        if (val) {
            return val.replace(/\;|\||\,/gi, '-');
        }
    }

    ,setCookie: function(name, value, seconds, domain) {
        domain = document.location.hostname;
        var expires = '';
        var expiresNow = '';
        var date = new Date();
        date.setTime(date.getTime() + (-1 * 1000));
        expiresNow = "; expires=" + date.toGMTString();

        if (typeof(seconds) != 'undefined') {
            date.setTime(date.getTime() + (seconds * 1000));
            expires = '; expires=' + date.toGMTString();
        }

        var type = typeof(value);
        type = type.toLowerCase();
        if (type != 'undefined' && type != 'string') {
            value = JSON.stringify(value);
        }

        // fix scoping issues
        // keep writing the old cookie, but make it expire
        document.cookie = name + '=' + value + expiresNow + '; path=/';

        // now just set the right one
        document.cookie = name + '=' + value + expires + '; path=/; domain=' + domain;
    }

    ,getCookie: function(name) {
        name = name + '=';
        var carray = document.cookie.split(';'), value;

        for (var i=0; i<carray.length; i++) {
            var c = carray[i];
            while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
                c = c.substring(1, c.length);
            }
            if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
                value = c.substring(name.length, c.length);
                try {
                    value = JSON.parse(value);
                } catch(ex) {}

                return value;
            }
        }

        return null;
    }

    ,deleteCookie: function(name) {
        this.setCookie(name, '', -1);
        this.setCookie(name, '', -1, document.location.hostname);
    }

    ,mapAdobeVars: function(s) {
        var vars = {
            pageName		: 'Page - Analytics Pagename'
            ,channel		: 'Page - Section Name'
            ,campaign		: 'Campaign - ID'
            ,currencyCode	: 'Page - Currency Code'

};

// async support fallback
(function(w) {
	var eventBuffer = [];
	if(w.appData) {
		if(Array.isArray(w.appData)) {
			eventBuffer = w.appData;
		} else {
			console.error('Elsevier DataLayer "window.appData" must be specified as array');
			return;
		}
    }

	w.appData = [];

	var oldPush = w.appData.push;

	var appDataPush = function() {
        oldPush.apply(w.appData, arguments);
        for(var i=0; i<arguments.length; i++) {
            var data = arguments[i];
            if(data.event) {
                if(data.event == 'pageLoad') {
                    w.pageDataTracker.trackPageLoad(data);
                } else {
                    w.pageDataTracker.trackEvent(data.event, data);
                }
            }
        }
	};

	w.appData.push = appDataPush;
	for(var i=0; i<eventBuffer.length; i++) {
	    var data = eventBuffer[i];
	    w.appData.push(data);
	}
})(window);

</script><script>_satellite["_runScript1"](function(event, target, Promise) {
_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: clearing tracking state");try{s.events="",s.linkTrackVars="",s.linkTrackEvents=""}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: s object - could not reset state.")}try{dispatcherData=JSON.parse(event.detail),window.ddqueue=window.ddqueue||[],window.ddqueue.push(dispatcherData),window.eventData=dispatcherData.eventData,window.pageData=dispatcherData.pageData,_satellite.track(dispatcherData.eventName)}catch(e){_satellite.logger.log("eventDispatcher: exception"),_satellite.logger.log(e)}

div#onetrust-consent-sdk #onetrust-banner-sdk{border-top:2px solid #eb6500!important;outline:1px solid transparent;box-shadow:none;padding:24px}div#onetrust-consent-sdk button:not(.ot-link-btn){background-color:#007398!important;border:2px solid #007398!important;color:#fff!important;height:48px!important;padding:0 publication milestones were reached at the journal that has published the article. Where applicable, activities on preceding journals at which the article was previously under consideration are not shown (for instance submission, revisions, rejection).</p><p class=\"u-margin-xs-bottom\">The publication milestones include:</p><ul class=\"key-dates-help-list u-margin-m-bottom u-padding-s-left\"><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Received</span>: The date the article was originally submitted to the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Revised</span>: The date the most recent revision of the article was submitted to the journal. Dates corresponding to intermediate revisions are not shown.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Accepted</span>: The date the article was accepted for publication in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Available online</span>: The date a version of the article was made available online in the journal.</li><li><span class=\"u-text-italic\">Version of Record</span>: The date the finalized version of the article was made available in the journal.</li></ul><p>More information on publishing policies can be found on the <a class=\"anchor anchor-secondary u-display-inline anchor-underline\" href=\"https://www.elsevier.com/about/policies-and-standards/publishing-ethics\" target=\"_blank\"><span class=\"anchor-text-container\"><span class=\"anchor-text\">Publishing Ethics Policies</span></span></a> page. id="social-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-social-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary u-margin-s-right button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2024.160499" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2024.160499</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="ab010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="as010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">The preparation is simple and highly efficient by a direct <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/coprecipitation" title="Learn more about coprecipitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coprecipitation</a> method.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">The effects of incorporating various sodium salts on the samples were explored.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">The sample possess minimal [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> defects and a relatively high Na<sup>+</sup> content.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">The sample shows a high initial capacity of 130.8&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="ab015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0020">Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) are widely used as cathodes for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to their stable framework structure, simple synthesis method, and low fabrication cost. However, during the synthesis process, a large number of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancies are easily caused, which leads to the destruction of crystal structure and the rapid decay of discharge capacity. In this work, the effect of sodium salts on lattice defects and electrochemical properties of iron hexacyanoferrates (FeHCF) was studied by adding different sodium salts (Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, NaCl, C<sub>6</sub>H<sub>5</sub>Na<sub>3</sub>O<sub>7</sub><span>, and EDTA-2Na) in the room-temperature <a href="/topics/materials-science/coprecipitation" title="Learn more about coprecipitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coprecipitation</a> method. It was found that the synthesis of FeHCF by adding Na</span><sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> based on the chelating agent can not only increase the atomic ratio of Na<sup>+</sup> but also effectively reduce [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystal-vacancy" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> and significantly increase the capacity contribution of low-spin Fe redox reaction. Due to the reduction of [Fe(CN)</span><sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a>, the crystal structure is not easy to be destroyed during the cycle process, and the cycle stability of FeHCF is significantly improved. The sample shows good electrochemical performance, with a discharge capacity of 130.8&nbsp;mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> in the first cycle and 114.3&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles. This work provides a new way to synthesize PBAs with low [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancy defects.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="ab005" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005"><span>Assisted by a chelating agent, a simple <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/coprecipitation" title="Learn more about coprecipitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coprecipitation</a> method was employed to synthesize Prussian blue analogues with low [Fe(CN)</span><sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a>, leading to exceptional </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a>.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0040"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt=""><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (117KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (117KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0169433224011929"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0169433224012091"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Prussian blue analogues</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Cathode</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Iron hexacyanoferrates</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>Room-temperature coprecipitation method</span></div><div id="k0030" class="keyword"><span>Sodium storage performance</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are assembled from transition metal nodes and organic ligands through coordination bonds <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a><span>. The <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composition</a> of these metal nodes and organic ligands can be adjusted, giving rise to various structures and morphologies </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a><span>. Due to their high <a href="/topics/chemistry/surface-area" title="Learn more about surface area from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface area</a> and exceptionally high porosity, they are widely applied in catalysis </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a><span>, <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/gas-adsorption" title="Learn more about gas adsorption from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">gas adsorption</a> and separation </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, sensing <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, energy storage <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a><span>, and other fields. These materials, especially in the energy storage domain, exhibit open, sturdy frameworks ideal for ion insertion and extraction, thereby enhancing cycling stability. As a typical metal–organic frameworks, Prussian Blue analogs (PBAs) possess numerous advantages. They are considered highly promising cathodes for <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a> owing to their stable, rigid open-frame structures, high voltage platforms, cost-effectiveness, simple preparation, and high theoretical capacity </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>. The general formula of PBAs is Na<sub>x</sub>M<sub>1</sub> [M<sub>2</sub>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>1-y</sub>·□<sub>y</sub>·nH<sub>2</sub>O (M<sub>1</sub> and M<sub>2</sub><span> are transition metal elements, □&nbsp;are cyanide vacancies, X, Y, and n are stoichiometry). Within PBAs, <a href="/topics/chemistry/cyano-group" title="Learn more about cyano groups from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">cyano groups</a><span> and transition <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/metal-ion" title="Learn more about metal ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">metal ions</a> organize into a three-dimensional framework based on M</span></span><sub>1</sub><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/tbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="triple bond">N<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">M<sub>2</sub> arrangement <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>. M<sub>1</sub><span> assumes a high <a href="/topics/chemistry/spin-state" title="Learn more about spin state from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">spin state</a> attached to the N atom of the cyanide group, while M</span><sub>2</sub><span> adopts a low spin state linked to the C atom of the cyanide group. PBAs exhibit large ionic channels, <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> ions occupy the large cubic voids within, facilitating rapid <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> ion migration </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a><span>. Due to the replaceability of <a href="/topics/chemistry/transition-metals" title="Learn more about transition metals from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transition metals</a>, they exhibit a high degree of electrochemical tunability </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>. When M<sub>2</sub> is Fe and M<sub>1</sub> is Ni or Cu, there is only one redox active site and the theoretical capacity is low (about 84&nbsp;mAh/g) due to the electrochemical inertness of Ni and Cu within the common electrolyte's voltage window. However, when both M<sub>1</sub> and M<sub>2</sub><span><span><span> are Fe, both transition metal ions exhibit redox activity. Accommodating the deintercalation of two <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a>, thereby yielding a higher theoretical specific capacity (approximately 170&nbsp;mAh/g). Synthesis methods for PBAs primarily include </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/hydrothermal-synthesis" title="Learn more about hydrothermal methods from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrothermal methods</a>, </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/coprecipitation" title="Learn more about coprecipitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coprecipitation</a><span><span><span>, and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/electrodeposition" title="Learn more about electrodeposition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrodeposition</a>. The </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/coprecipitation" title="Learn more about coprecipitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coprecipitation</a> method for synthesizing iron-based PBAs offers advantages such as facile preparation of </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/nanomaterial" title="Learn more about nanomaterials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanomaterials</a><span><span> with small, uniformly distributed particle sizes, low reaction temperatures, simple processes, cost-effectiveness, short cycles, and straightforward synthesis. Compared with the hydrothermal method and the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrodeposition" title="Learn more about electrodeposition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrodeposition</a> method, the </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/coprecipitation" title="Learn more about coprecipitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coprecipitation</a> method is more suitable for commercial large-scale production.</span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span>However, the synthesis of iron hexacyanoferrates (FeHCF) using the <a href="/topics/chemistry/coprecipitation" title="Learn more about coprecipitation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coprecipitation</a> method involves the rapid precipitation reaction of Fe</span><sup>2+</sup><span> and sodium <a href="/topics/chemistry/ferrocyanide" title="Learn more about ferrocyanide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ferrocyanide</a><span> (Na₄Fe(CN)₆) in an aqueous solution. This swift <a href="/topics/materials-science/crystallization" title="Learn more about crystallization process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallization process</a> leads to a considerable presence of [Fe(CN)</span></span><sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancies within the crystal structure of PBAs. Specifically, this occurs because, during synthesis, Fe<sup>2+</sup> readily forms hydrated ferrous ions when coordinated with water molecules in the aqueous solution. As hydrated ferrous ions combine with [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> to construct a three-dimensional PBA framework, the ferrous ion inadvertently introduces coordination water into the product lattice. As these coordinating water molecules occupy the six vertices of the octahedral cavity, the intended coordination of ferrocyanide ions with Fe<sup>2+</sup> becomes hindered, resulting in a significant accumulation of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancies within the lattice. The presence of numerous [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancies not only reduces electrochemically active sites, significantly lowering the actual capacity of PBAs, but also adversely affects their stability during cycling. This impact results in structural degradation and a rapid decline in capacity. Hence, alleviating the presence of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> and controlling water content during the synthesis process stands as a pressing challenge for FeHCF </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">To address this issue, researchers have focused on synthesizing low-defect FeHCF by primarily reducing the crystallization rate. Zhang's team successfully obtained Na<sub>1.7</sub>FeFe(CN)<sub>6</sub><span>, which exhibited excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a><span><span>, by utilizing <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-citrate" title="Learn more about sodium citrate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium citrate</a> as a chelating agent to control the </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/synthesis-reaction" title="Learn more about synthesis reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">synthesis reaction</a> rate of PBAs. This approach improved the sodium content of the material while reducing [Fe(CN)</span></span><sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystal-vacancy" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a>. The Na</span><sub>1.7</sub>FeFe(CN)<sub>6</sub> sample maintained a reversible specific capacity of 90.9&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup><span> at a <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 200&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g</span><sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>. Similarly, Cao and colleagues synthesized PBAs with significantly reduced structural defects and greatly improved electrochemical performance by incorporating sodium citrate and sodium chloride as additives. Their optimized material exhibited a remarkable capacity retention rate of 78&nbsp;% after 3700 cycles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a><span>. In another study, Chou's research group controlled various reaction conditions, such as introducing a chelating agent, maintaining an <a href="/topics/chemistry/inert-atmosphere" title="Learn more about inert atmosphere from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inert atmosphere</a><span>, and employing a slow dripping technique, to synthesize a sample with higher sodium content and minimal <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a>. This sample displayed an initial specific capacity of 115&nbsp;mAh g</span></span><sup>−1</sup> within the voltage range of 2.0–4.2&nbsp;V <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a><span>. Furthermore, Wang and Luo et al. augmented the synthesis process of FeHCF with the addition of NaCl. As the NaCl concentration increased, the occurrence of vacancy defects significantly decreased, leading to improved <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> and electrochemical performance. Specifically, their sample exhibited a discharge capacity of 120&nbsp;mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> in the first cycle at 80&nbsp;°C and maintained a reversible specific capacity of 57&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>after 500 cycles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0045">This study proposes the incorporation of sodium salts to facilitate the synthesis of iron hexacyanoferrates through room-temperature coprecipitation, building upon the addition of a chelating agent, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Scheme 1</span></span></a>. By adding various sodium salts, their impact on the morphology, structure, and electrochemical performance were investigated. Upon the addition of Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, the sample's formula transformed from Na<sub>0.43</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.26</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.29</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.45</sub>□<sub>0.10</sub>∙5.04H<sub>2</sub>O to Na<sub>1.07</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.30</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.14</sub>□<sub>0.12</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>∙4.20H<sub>2</sub>O This resulted in a significant increase in the Na<sup>+</sup> content, effectively reducing [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancy defects and markedly enhancing structural stability and electrochemical performance. The sample exhibited an impressive discharge capacity of 130.8&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> in the first cycle, maintaining a capacity of 114.3&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr7.jpg" height="261" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (177KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (177KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0055"><span class="label">Scheme 1</span>. Schematic illustration of the synthesis for the sample FeHCF-1 and the corresponding crystal structure.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Synthesis</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050"><span>The samples of FeHCF were synthesized by the simple room-temperature coprecipitation method. 1&nbsp;mmol sodium <a href="/topics/chemistry/ferrocyanide" title="Learn more about ferrocyanide from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ferrocyanide</a> (Na</span><sub>4</sub> [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub><span>]) was dissolved in 50&nbsp;ml <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/deionized-water" title="Learn more about deionized water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">deionized water</a>, named solution A; 1&nbsp;mmol ferrous sulfate heptahydrate (FeSO</span><sub>4</sub>·7H<sub>2</sub><span>O), 1&nbsp;mmol <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/citric-acid" title="Learn more about citric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">citric acid</a> and 8&nbsp;mmol Na</span><sup>+</sup> equivalent sodium salt (4&nbsp;mmol sodium sulphate-Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>) were dissolved in 50&nbsp;ml deionized water, named solution B. Solution A was quickly added to the solution B, and then the mixed solution was aged at room temperature (25&nbsp;°C) for 12&nbsp;h. Finally, the obtained precipitate was washed several times with deionized water and ethanol to remove impurities, and vacuum dried at 120&nbsp;°C for 24&nbsp;h to obtain iron hexacyanoferrates (denoted as FeHCF-1). To compare the influence of different sodium salts on the synthesis of PBAs, based on the synthesis scheme of FeHCF-1, 4&nbsp;mmol Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub><span> was replaced by 8&nbsp;mmol sodium chloride (NaCl), 8/3mmol <a href="/topics/chemistry/sodium-citrate" title="Learn more about sodium citrate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium citrate</a>, 4&nbsp;mmol ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid disodium salt (EDTA-2Na) were added to solution B, and the synthesized samples were respectively named FeHCF-2, FeHCF-3, and FeHCF-4. To compare the difference without adding sodium salt, the addition of 4&nbsp;mmol Na</span><sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> in the synthesis scheme of FeHCF-1 was canceled, and the synthesized sample was named FeHCF-0.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Material characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055"><span>The phase structure of the samples was characterized by X-ray diffraction（XRD, D8 ADVANCE, Bruker）using Cu Kα radiation (λ&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.1541&nbsp;nm) with a scan range of 2θ&nbsp;=&nbsp;5°–80°. The organic functional groups in samples were characterized by <a href="/topics/chemistry/fourier-transform" title="Learn more about Fourier transform from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fourier transform</a> infrared spectrometer (FTIR, VERTEX80V, Bruker) in the spectral range of 650–4000&nbsp;cm</span><sup>−1</sup><span>. <a href="/topics/chemistry/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about Thermogravimetric analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Thermogravimetric analysis</a> (TGA, TGA8000, HITACHI) was used to determine the water content in the samples. The samples were heated from room temperature to 600&nbsp;°C at a rate of 10&nbsp;°C·min</span><sup>−1</sup> in the N<sub>2</sub><span><span> atmosphere. The chemical states of the elements were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB 250Xi, THERMO FISHER), using an Al Kα ray source. The morphology and <a href="/topics/chemistry/elemental-analysis" title="Learn more about elemental analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental analysis</a><span> of the samples were characterized by the scanning electron microscope (SEM, SU8220, HITACHI). At the same time, the X-ray energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) was used to analyze the element surface of the samples. The microstructure of the samples after 100 cycles was analyzed by field emission <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (HRTEM, Tecnai G2 F20, FEI). The accurate quantification of elements is obtained by inductively </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/inductively-coupled-plasma" title="Learn more about inductively coupled plasma from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">inductively coupled plasma</a> (ICP, Thermo Fisher iCAP PRO).</span></div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060"><span><span><span>The FeHCF active material, <a href="/topics/chemistry/carbon-nanotube" title="Learn more about carbon nanotubes from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon nanotubes</a> (CNTs), and </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/polyvinylidene-fluoride" title="Learn more about polyvinylidene fluoride from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polyvinylidene fluoride</a><span><span> (PVDF) were mixed in N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP) at a mass ratio of 7:2:1. The electrode paste was obtained by mechanical <a href="/topics/chemistry/ball-milling" title="Learn more about ball milling from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ball milling</a>, then the paste was coated on </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/aluminum" title="Learn more about aluminum from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">aluminum</a> foil, and the </span></span><a href="/topics/chemistry/working-electrode" title="Learn more about working electrode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">working electrode</a> was obtained by vacuum drying at 120&nbsp;°C for 20&nbsp;h, its mass loading is about 1.02&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm</span><sup>−2</sup><span>. The working electrode was used as the cathode, sodium metal was used as the anode, the <a href="/topics/chemistry/glass-fiber" title="Learn more about glass fiber from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glass fiber</a> filter paper of Whatman GF/D was used as the separator, and the mixed solvent of 1&nbsp;mol/L NaClO</span><sub>4</sub><span><span><span> of ethylene carbonate (EC) and <a href="/topics/chemistry/propene" title="Learn more about propylene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">propylene</a> carbonate (PC) (vol/vol&nbsp;=&nbsp;1:1) with 5&nbsp;vol% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) as electrolyte. They were assembled in the argon-filled glove box to assemble 2032 type coin cells. Galvanostatic charge/discharge tests are tested by the LAND testing system in the voltage window of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V. The galvanostatic intermittent </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about titration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">titration</a> technique (GITT) tests were performed using the LAND testing system to measure the chemical </span><a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a><span> of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ions from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ions</a>. A current pulse of 50&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g</span></span><sup>−1</sup> was applied for 5&nbsp;min, then left to stand for 30&nbsp;min, and then cycled to the set voltage following the two steps above. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests were performed using the electrochemical workstation (CHI660e) with the scanning voltage range of 2–4&nbsp;V at the scanning rate of 0.2&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>−1</sup><span>. <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) was performed on the CHI660e electrochemical workstation. The frequency is set between 0.01&nbsp;Hz and 100&nbsp;kHz. All electrochemical tests were performed at room temperature.</span></div></section></section><section id="s0030"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="s0035"><h3 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Morphology and structure</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">Due to the rapid nucleation rate, PBAs synthesized through the room-temperature coprecipitation method often exhibit an increased presence of [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup> vacancies in their crystal structure. This study explores the influence of various sodium salts on the lattice structure and morphology of PBAs using the room-temperature coprecipitation method, in conjunction with a chelating agent. The crystal structure of samples, synthesized with and without the addition of different sodium salts, was characterized using powder XRD (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>a). All diffraction peaks for FeHCF-0, FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3 are consistent, signifying identical crystal structures. These peaks correspond to the face-centered cubic structure of PBAs with the Fm-3&nbsp;m space group (JCPDS No. 52-1907, a&nbsp;=&nbsp;b&nbsp;=&nbsp;c&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.0199&nbsp;nm) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>. Notably, XRD patterns reveal that these samples maintain a typical cubic phase, and the introduction of sodium salts does not induce any phase transitions <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a><span>. Furthermore, diffraction peaks for FeHCF-0, FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3 exhibit sharpness, indicating good <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a><span>. The addition of sodium salts (FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3) results in even narrower and sharper peaks compared to the sample without sodium salts (FeHCF-0). Suggesting an enhanced <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a> when sodium salts are incorporated in the room-temperature coprecipitation method. However, when using EDTA-2Na as the sodium salt, sample FeHCF-4 displays additional impurity peaks (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>a), indicating the generation of other impurity phases during the synthesis process. To explore the impact of various sodium salts on sample morphology in the room-temperature coprecipitation method, all samples were characterized by SEM. In <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b, FeHCF-0, synthesized without sodium salt, exhibits small particles and severe agglomeration due to rapid precipitation and nucleation. This is a hindrance to sodium ion insertion/extraction during charge and discharge <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>. FeHCF-1, synthesized with Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub><span> assistance, demonstrates uniform-sized <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a> with excellent dispersion (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>c). Its <a href="/topics/materials-science/particle-size-analysis" title="Learn more about particle size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">particle size distribution</a>, about 45.2&nbsp;nm (inset in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c), favors shorter sodium ion diffusion paths, enhancing electrode–electrolyte contact and facilitating sodium ion transport. The morphology of FeHCF-2 assisted by the addition of sodium citrate is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>d. Due to sodium citrate chelation of Fe<sup>2+</sup>, slowing Fe<sup>2+</sup> release when mixed with Na<sub>4</sub>Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub> solution (solution A). FeHCF-2, assisted by sodium citrate addition, exhibits cubic morphology with distinct edges and uniform particle size <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>. FeHCF-3, synthesized with NaCl addition, displays significant nanoparticle agglomeration (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>e). Meanwhile, FeHCF-4, assisted by EDTA-2Na addition, comprises rod-like structures, 5–15&nbsp;μm in length (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>b), differing notably from other samples. Which confirming to XRD findings. SEM patterns reveal that adding sodium salts, particularly Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, in the room-temperature coprecipitation method effectively mitigates PBAs nanoparticle agglomeration. Moreover, he element distribution and content analysis of elements Na and Fe on the surface of the samples were measured by EDS. EDS results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a><span>) showcase uniform distribution of Na and Fe elements in <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nanoparticle" title="Learn more about nanoparticles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanoparticles</a>. From the element ratios in the EDS results of the samples with the addition of different sodium salts, it can be proved that the addition of sodium salts can increase the sodium content in the obtained PBAs to different degrees.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr1.jpg" height="548" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (509KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (509KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. <span><span>(a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> patterns of all samples. (b–e) </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about SEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEM</a> image of the samples, (b) FeHCF-0, (c) FeHCF-1, (d) FeHCF-2, (e) FeHCF-3. (f) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a><span> patterns image of FeHCF-1. (g, h) <a href="/topics/chemistry/tem-image" title="Learn more about HRTEM images from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM images</a> of FeHCF-1. (i) The crystal structure model of FeHCF-1.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070">High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) measurements were used to further study the crystal structure of FeHCF-1 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>f–h). The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structure-of-solids" title="Learn more about solid structure of from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid structure of</a> the sample FeHCF-1 can be seen from </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a><span>, which shows that the sample is a uniformly distributed solid structure. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a> patterns in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>f is the shows that the sample is <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/polycrystal" title="Learn more about polycrystal from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polycrystal</a>, and correspond to the crystal faces of (1</span>&nbsp;0&nbsp;0), (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;0), (1&nbsp;1&nbsp;1), and (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;0). The HRTEM image of <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>g shows clear lattice fringes. The lattice spacings of 0.40&nbsp;nm, 0.41&nbsp;nm and 0.53&nbsp;nm can be indexed to the (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;1), (2&nbsp;1&nbsp;1) and (2&nbsp;0&nbsp;<span>0) crystal faces of PBAs. This can be verified from the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a><span> patterns obtained through <a href="/topics/chemistry/fourier-transform" title="Learn more about Fourier transform from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fourier transform</a> in the inset of </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>g. In addition, a partial enlarged view of the lattice fringes (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>h) and the crystal structure model of the sample FeHCF-1 view at [0&nbsp;1&nbsp;−2] (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>i) is depicted for convenient visualization.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075"><span>FTIR, TGA, XPS, and <a href="/topics/chemistry/inductively-coupled-plasma" title="Learn more about ICP from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ICP</a><span> were utilized to determine the chemical <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composition</a><span> and offer a quantitative description of the sample constituents. FTIR provides essential functional group information, aiding in the identification of the <a href="/topics/chemistry/chemical-substance-type" title="Learn more about material's chemical from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">material's chemical</a> composition. In </span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>, with the exception of sample FeHCF-4, the absorption peak positions for the other samples align. Suggesting similar structural compositions, consistent with the XRD findings. FeHCF-0, FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3 exhibit robust absorption peaks at 2071&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup><span>, arising from the <a href="/topics/chemistry/stretching-vibration" title="Learn more about stretching vibration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">stretching vibration</a> of </span><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/tbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="triple bond">N coordinated to Fe<sup>II</sup>—a characteristic feature of PBAs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>. Notably, no discernible absorption peaks appear in regions with slightly higher binding energy, indicating exclusive coordination between Fe<sup>II</sup> and <img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/tbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="triple bond">N, with minimal coordination between Fe<sup>III</sup> and <img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/tbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="triple bond">N <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>. Furthermore, the absorption peak at 1610&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup><span> corresponds to the <a href="/topics/chemistry/bending-vibration" title="Learn more about bending vibration from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">bending vibration</a> of O</span><img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond"><span>H, affirming the presence of water in the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystal-lattice" title="Learn more about crystal lattice from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystal lattice</a> </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>. Additionally, a minor absorption peak around 1000&nbsp;cm<sup>−1</sup> is observed in both FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-2, indicative of various chemical environments associated with C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" style="vertical-align: middle;" alt="single bond">O bonds <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>. This can be attributed to the presence of crystalline water and residual citrate ions in FeHCF-2.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr2.jpg" height="511" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (563KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (563KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0169433224012121-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>(a) FTIR spectra of all samples. (b) <a href="/topics/chemistry/thermogravimetric-analysis" title="Learn more about TGA from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">TGA</a> curves. (c) Wide-scan </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> spectrum. (d) High-resolution spectra of Fe 2p XPS spectrum of the sample FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">To assess water content in samples synthesized via the room-temperature coprecipitation method, TGA tests were conducted on FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1, with results depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span><span><span>b. FeHCF-1 exhibits negligible weight loss up to 100&nbsp;°C, suggesting removal of adsorbed water during material preparation. Conversely, FeHCF-0 shows significant weight loss before 100&nbsp;°C, attributed to increased <a href="/topics/materials-science/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> enhancing its adsorption capacity and accumulating </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/surface-water" title="Learn more about surface water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface water</a> during synthesis. At 200&nbsp;°C, FeHCF-1 experiences a 6.5&nbsp;% weight loss, while FeHCF-0 undergoes a 23.2&nbsp;% loss, attributable to </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/interstitial-water" title="Learn more about interstitial water from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">interstitial water</a> evaporation in the lattice structure. Between 200&nbsp;°C and 260&nbsp;°C, FeHCF-1 and FeHCF-0 register 8.5&nbsp;% and 5.6&nbsp;% weight losses, respectively, linked to coordinated water elimination. Above 260&nbsp;°C, samples weight losses are ascribed to cyano decomposition in the PBAs </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>. Consequently, water content is determined to be 28.8&nbsp;wt% in FeHCF-0 and 15.0&nbsp;wt% in FeHCF-1.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085">The elemental composition of samples FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1, along with the valence state of transition metal Fe, was determined using XPS. Analysis of the wide-scan XPS spectrum (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c) reveals that both FeHCF-0 and FeHCF-1 comprise elements C, N, O, Fe, and Na. In the high-resolution XPS spectrum of Fe 2p (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d), distinctive peaks at 708.7 and 721.6&nbsp;eV correspond to Fe<sup>II</sup>2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Fe<sup>II</sup>2p<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively. Additionally, weaker peaks at 712.8 and 724.7&nbsp;eV are associated with Fe<sup>III</sup>2p<sub>3/2</sub> and Fe<sup>III</sup>2p<sub>1/2</sub>, respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a><span>. The XPS findings indicate that a fraction of ferrous iron in the synthesized FeHCF-1 underwent <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> to ferric iron during the room-temperature coprecipitation process. Calculation of the shadow area ratio from XPS data (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>) provided the Fe<sup>II</sup> to Fe<sup>III</sup> ratio, which exhibited no significant change. However, the Na/Fe ratio in FeHCF-1 (1.07) notably surpassed that in FeHCF-0 (0.43), suggesting that introducing Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> during PBA synthesis via room-temperature coprecipitation substantially increased sodium content, as evidenced by the ICP results in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0060" name="bs0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a>. Consequently, the role and positioning of iron in the crystal structure underwent evident alterations, effectively enhancing the sample's structure. Based on TGA, XPS, and ICP results, the structural formula for FeHCF-0 is Na<sub>0.43</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.26</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.29</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.45</sub>□<sub>0.10</sub>·3.06H<sub>2</sub>O, and that of FeHCF-1 is Na<sub>1.07</sub>Fe<sup>III</sup><sub>0.30</sub>Fe<sup>II</sup><sub>0.14</sub>□<sub>0.12</sub> [Fe<sup>II</sup>(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sub>0.56</sub>·1.65H<sub>2</sub>O. Analysis of these formulas reveals that the vacancy defect in FeHCF-0 involves [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span>, with a ratio of <a href="/topics/chemistry/crystal-vacancy" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a> to node sites at 0.18, while FeHCF-1 exhibits vacancies in the form of Fe, with a ratio of 0.21. Although the introduction of Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> did not decrease the sample's <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vacancy-defect" title="Learn more about vacancy defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">vacancy defects</a>, it did facilitate the conversion of larger [Fe(CN)</span><sub>6</sub>]<sup>4−</sup><span> vacancies into smaller Fe vacancies. This transformation led to a reduction in total vacancy volume, thereby enhancing the specific capacity and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a> of the samples.</span></div></section><section id="s0040"><h3 id="st065" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Electrochemistry performance</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090"><span>To investigate the impact of sodium salt addition on the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical properties</a> of synthesized FeHCF, galvanostatic charge–discharge tests were conducted across all samples within a voltage range of 2.0–4.0&nbsp;V. </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>a illustrates the cycle performances of various samples at a <a href="/topics/chemistry/current-density" title="Learn more about current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">current density</a> of 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g</span><sup>−1</sup>. The specific capacity of samples FeHCF-1, FeHCF-2, and FeHCF-3 markedly surpasses that of sample FeHCF-0. In particular, the initial cycle discharge capacity of FeHCF-1, synthesized with the addition of Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, reaches 130.8&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. Even after 100 cycles, the discharge capacity remains at 114.3&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, resulting in an impressive capacity retention rate of 87.4&nbsp;%. In contrast, FeHCF-0, synthesized without sodium salt, exhibits a modest initial discharge capacity of 82&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, decreasing to 58.3&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 100 cycles, with a capacity retention rate of only 71&nbsp;%. Additionally, the capacity retention rates for FeHCF-2, FeHCF-3, and FeHCF-4 are 67&nbsp;%, 58.4&nbsp;%, and 73.3&nbsp;%, respectively. The addition of sodium salt significantly enhances the specific discharge capacity of FeHCF. Certain sodium salts, such as Na<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub>, also contribute to the improved cycling stability of FeHCF synthesized through the room-temperature coprecipitation method. Notably, the cycles of FeHCF-1 exhibit no discernible polarization, indicating superior reversibility during the charging/discharging process. The charge/discharge voltage curves for FeHCF-1 at different cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>b) reveal two distinct charge/discharge voltage plateaus. The higher voltage plateau corresponds to the <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> of low-spin iron associated with C atoms in Na</span><sub>x</sub>Fe [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub><span>], while the lower voltage plateau corresponds to the <a href="/topics/chemistry/redox-reactions" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> of high-spin iron linked to N atoms in Na</span><sub>x</sub>Fe [Fe(CN)<sub>6</sub>]. Despite the chemical formula indicating a higher quantity of low-spin iron in FeHCF-1, the redox activity of high-spin iron surpasses that of low-spin iron.
